body:
Thanks @keunseob! fixing the health protocol so it is engaged when no responses are received and to account for health correctly in that case will achieve the result you want and fix the bug so the behavior is what's intended . 

I didn't understand your comment about fast timers - do you mind rephrasing or claryifing your statement?
i suggest making the message const changes in another pr
Added link to REST interface doc.
@starpit think this is good now?
Thanks.
@mdeuser Let me know if this is what you were thinking.
@dubeejw is there a specific way that you would like the long names to be truncated? Has that already been discussed?  At least in that issue it doesn't seem like anything has been yet.
@jessealva, we can address the name truncations in a different PR. I opened a separate issue for it here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/2484.

it does indeed look like the closure no longer captures the Promise, thus obviating any need for weak references, in this case.

it is also worth noting that the original impl likely had a race bug, as it created a Promise object that, for a brief moment, was only weakly referenced.

this change *does* require that the promise be resolved, in the "timeout/catastrophe" scenario. i am trusting that this is done elsewhere. it might be worth a comment in the closure documenting how this is done?
it is: @starpit https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/core/controller/src/main/scala/whisk/core/loadBalancer/LoadBalancerService.scala#L134
Thanks, giving that a shot

@mdeuser, @dubee - I still need to update docs, but this is my rough draft for the PR. Still have some other functionality I'd like to add in that @rabbah talks about in the original issue. Just wanted to make you aware of this PR. Thanks!
most actions will not have annotations - i suggest dropping the "warning" prefix.
when no annotation is present, you can still construct a summary of the bound parameters - which should be part of the summary anyway imo.
I'll close the ticket though since the approach of wrapping in single quote will work for most cases, and it might boil down to shell escaping issues, which is probably outside the scope.

Indeed - this should do it:

```
> export P='"1234"'
> wsk action invoke echo -r -p p $P
{
    "p": "1234"
}
```
@rabbah - this is a fix for limiting large http body data being dumped out when the --verbose or --debug flag is specified.
@mdeuser, please review.

@rabbah, is this issue still valid? Here's the output I get with the current CLI:
```
$ wsk action create a --docker a
ok: created action a
$ wsk action create b --docker b
ok: created action b
$ wsk action create s a,b --sequence
ok: created action s
$ wsk action update s --sequence
error: Invalid argument(s). An action name and code artifact are required.
Run 'wsk --help' for usage.
```
that's better.

As part of the work done on this task (https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/2326) we've determined that the CLI should not be responsible for sorting entity names. Instead we should try to retrieve the entity names from the database using a view that sorts for us. The type of sort should be controllable via a flag passed to the REST interface. 

We can sort the entity names in the CLI as shown below. However, when the `--limit` or `--skip` flags are specified, an unexpected list is returned. From the example below, a user would expect to see the entities `9992` and `aaaaaaa` when using a `--limit` with an argument of 2. This is not the case in the example below because `NoSQL DB-em_Credentials-1` and `cloudant_Credentials-1` are returned from the server since the backend sorts entities by creation date.

```
wsk package list
packages
/namespace/9992                                           private
/namespace/aaaaaaa                                        private
/namespace/aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa private
/namespace/asdfasdfasdfasedf2                             private
/namespace/cloudant_Credentials-1                         private
/namespace/NoSQL DB-6v_Credentials-1                      private
/namespace/NoSQL DB-em_Credentials-1                      private
/namespace/Hub-ju_Credentials-1                           private
```

```
$ wsk package list --limit 2
packages
/namespace/cloudant_Credentials-1                         private
/namespace/NoSQL DB-em_Credentials-1                      private
```

> we've determined that the CLI should not be responsible for sorting entity names. Instead we should try to retrieve the entity names from the database using a view that sorts for us. 

hmm... why? and are you imaging this is a second view in addition to the one sorted by date or in lieu of?

Thanks Mark - we can hold this pr back until then since I scrubbed experimental from all but the js actions. Or I can remove these bits from this pr to get the test cleanups in sooner.
Rebased to pick up #2437

@lzbj - in general, Go seems to treat errors as stucts and not pointers to structs.  https://golang.org/pkg/errors/  

since WskError is just another implementation of the error interface, i recommend consistency in the treatment of errors - not as pointers, but as structs

PG2 1822 - Failed
PG1 1804
The cleanest solution is to ignore the user defined headers. @dubeejw thoughts wrt akka port?
@markusthoemmes rebased this to master; pg4/552 running since I couldn't verify the above noted pg.
PG1 1804 - Passed
@rabbah if OW ignores my headers, it should let me know it did so and educate me on what to do to make it right. Otherwise I'll have a hard-time figuring out where my headers went.

@rabbah - just wanted to follow up on the 'try to create a summary from the parameters attached' suggestion.  maybe we create a union of the annotated parameters + default parameters.  what do you think about also including some designation of whether or not the the parameter is `final`-ized?
i like it.

warn you how?

the annotations are not available inside the action: so we can't easily generate a log message for the action.

the headers are generated during the http request termination; so at that point, a warning can be generated but how do we communicate it back to the user? we could fail the activation with a 40x level status code.

the more involved solution is to accept the action specified headers and override the default ones; this makes the custom cors annotation almost unnecessary.
@markusthoemmes, can you review this one?

I think this one is more about the other verbs and not `OPTIONS`, that we are adding default CORS headers.
I can see how `web-custom-options` can only be applied to `OPTIONS` were it says to the system let the request reach the action and the action will handle the response.

For the other verbs (i.e. GET, POST, etc..), I guess I can see a valid case to say that if the action response contains a header the controller should not add this header and respect the action response as priority, meaning only add any of the 3 CORS headers only if they are missing.

I don't see how we can make it consistent unless we ignore the response from the action wrt headers - since without the annotation the OPTIONS response will be X and the actually response from the non-OPTIONS verb may be Y. Or we design something else entirely.
@csantanapr - so that the cli does not break it's existing syntax, what do you think about adding a flag to the command to redirect the output to stdout (ie. `wsk sdk install bashauto --stdout`) ?
@rabbah that reminded me, that [this](https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/tools/vagrant/Vagrantfile#L158) also needs to be updated.
@mdeuser since is currently not mentioned in the docs, I think is low risk if we change the API on the syntax
yes, it's probably lightly used.  would like some way to notify downstream folks of the change though. :-)
I have used IP address instead inside the ansible inventory file. Sorry, it was not a bug.

That's not the test at failure, those are:

- `succeed but truncate logs, if log size exceeds its limit`
- `succeed but truncate result, if result exceeds its limit (blocking: $blocking)`
@dubeejw I'm wondering if the `--shared` flags in the `wsk package create` and `wsk package update` commands still still valid if there's nothing to display this state.. ?

As @rabbah (I believe) is indicating... 
https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/tree/master/tools/cli/go-whisk-cli/wski18n/resources

and specifically the translated map:
```
{
    "id": "Unable to create action '{{.name}}': {{.err}}",
    "translation": "Unable to create action '{{.name}}': {{.err}}"
},
```

@mdeuser, the `--shared` flag for package update and create set the `published` field that is sent to the backend making the package public or not. The `--shared` flag for package list was meant to display only public or private package depending on the argument passed to it, but that feature does not exist in the backend. That means the flag is still needed for package create and update.

@rabbah - looks like this pr is not only doing some scala cleanup, but is also removing the api-experimental related test code as well as the api-experimental cli/go code...  perhaps these are best done in separate prs?

api-experimental removal will also involve some other changes in ansible, health monitoring, gradle task targets

Specifically the id in the translation file should be a well known constant, like

```
{
    "id": "ACTION_CREATE_UNABLE",
    "translation": "Unable to create action '{{.name}}': {{.err}}"
},
```
ok. sounds good.  looks like none of the other cli `list` commands (action, rule, trigger) currently support filtering based on the scope.  code removal looks good to me
good find - The reactive pool is ready to go online and will be the supported pool going forward. @DanLavine et al. do you have a plan for rolling this out for kube?

Keunseob Kim's ICLA received by Apache @rabbah

> Due to Alphabetize no longer being a CLI issue,

can you elaborate this?
Due to recent discussions with @mdeuser, @bpoole16 and I have concluded this issue is best handled on the server side, not from the CLI.

@rabbah - with regard to @mdeuser 's suggestion for getting unions of annotated and default parameters: listing the union of these parameters can be kind of confusing all at once without at least differentiating the bound from the annotated parameters. For example:  
```
package /whisk.system/cloudant: Cloudant database service
   (parameters: bluemixServiceName, dbname, host, password, username, apihost, overwrite)
```
Which ones do I actually have access to? Which are/aren't important? I thought about something like:
```
package /whisk.system/cloudant: Cloudant database service
   (parameters: *bluemixServiceName, *dbname, *host, *password, *username, apihost, overwrite)
```
where parameters with * are bound, and if they were finalized they could have a different prefix. This could still be cumbersome, however, especially since we are at the mercy of users creating their own metadata parameters that may/may not even be useful. Thoughts?

I'm not convinced - this will require an API change, a change in the view (2x the space), and changes in the controller. For something that's a client side rendering. Seems like over complicating a simple change otherwise. Happy to discuss further.
Also perhaps a good discussion to have on the apache dev list.

I like the * to indicate bound vs not bound. the point of the summary is to quickly show the user what the parameters are - only the catalogs have these and the common case is for users to just create parameters, not annotations.

in general the annotations are meant for documentation - they are currently not checked, so your point is right, it could get messy... but for the system/curated packages, i don't think it will be an issue since the goal is to document not obfuscate.

an alternative you alluded to it show the annotations separately from the parameters.
@mdeuser This is the issue we discussed, wondering if there are any tips or preferred styles for updating the String references?
